bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Eugene Lindsay Opie, 1873-1971, was a physician, pathologist and medical administrator. He was a pioneer in investigating the cause of diabetes and was the first person to observe that injury to the cells of the Island of Langerhans caused the disease. Except for the effects of chemicals, he contributed much to the knowledge of tuberculosis and he is credited with pioneer findings in fundamentals aspects of inflammation, necrosis, liver pathology and in pneumonia and influenza epidemics in military camps. The book he wrote on the pancreas was for many years the classic textbook in the field.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists, primarily, of administrative correspondence from 1904 to 1970, but it is in discreet portions covering only the years during which Dr. Opie was actively involved with The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.
Included are groups of photographs covering various activities and a group of portraits.

Included with this collection are seven letter from Wm. Gies for The Society for Experimental Biology and Medicine to Simon Flexner (1907-1908) in which he suggests Dr. Opie as a secretary of the Society to succeed Wm. Gies.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers of Eugene Lindsay Opie were deposited with the Rockefeller University archives - on June 1980 by Office of Faculty and Student Records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains photographs; biographical articles; letters between Wm. Gies and Simon Flexner; a listing from RIMR Minutes of Scientific Directors' Board Meetings (1901-1911) prepared by Dr. Opie, RIMR employment record for Dr. Opie, some newspaper articles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This correspondence deals primarily with the grants from The Jane Coffin Childs Memorial Fund for Medical Research for support of Dr, Opie's research. A letter, dated June 10, 1941 signed by J.D. Rockefeller, Jr. expresses his willingness to accept such grants provided the Board of of Trustees so votes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes additional financial support for Dr. Opie, arranged with RIMR by Dr. Rivers. 1970 correspondence is with Dr. Opie's family members who are anxious that he discontinue living in New York City and coming to the laboratory.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
